dataset.title: Reef Check kelp forest long-term MPA monitoring: invertebrate data

abstract.para: Reef Check California (RCCA) invertebrate surveys consist of visual surveys performed by scuba divers. At each site, buddy teams of divers conduct eighteen 30 m x 2 m benthic transects, to monitor key species of invertebrates. Each site is divided into two "zones" by depth (shallow 5-12 meters and deep 12-18 meters - or from offshore to inshore at sites with little depth variation) to assure that samples are distributed across the face of a reef from inshore to offshore. Invertebrates are counted on 6 transects per site (3 transects in each zone). To be counted invertebrates have to be larger than 2.5 centimeters. Gorgonians and ‘large anemones‘ have to be larger than 10 centimeters to be counted. Each transect is a 2m wide x 30m long swath along the seafloor.
The long-term California MPA boundary and project info tables referenced in this dataset can be found as a separate dataset here: https://opc.dataone.org/view/doi:10.25494/P6V884

intellectualRights.para: This work is dedicated to the public domain under the Creative Commons Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication. To view a copy of this dedication, visit https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Reef Check data are collected at sites inside and outside of MPAs along the entire California coast. Specific site locations are listed in the following table: Reef Check kelp forest long-term MPA monitoring sites

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: Thirty two marine invertebrate taxa are identified to family, genus, or in most cases species. Taxa are listed in the following table: RCCA_invertebrate_lookup_table.csv

description.para: Invertebrate data are collected by counting organisms along 30m long by 2m wide transects along the sea floor on rocky reef habitat. Six transects are done per site.

Sites are located on shallow rocky reefs and in kelp forest at depth between 5 and 20 meters. RCCA aims to sample each site once a year around the same time of year. Sites are located inside and outside of MPAs so that trends can be compared between protected areas and areas open to fishing. 34 taxa (in most cases to the species level) are counted.

samplingDescription.para: Reef Check California (RCCA) surveys consist of visual surveys performed by scuba divers. At each site, buddy teams of divers conduct eighteen 30 m x 2 m benthic transects, to monitor key species of fishes (35 species), invertebrates (33 species) and algae (5 species & 4 invasive species) and to characterize the reef substrate and relief. Each site is divided into two "zones" by depth (shallow 5-12 meters and deep 12-18 meters - or from offshore to inshore at sites with little depth variation) to assure that samples are distributed across the face of a reef from inshore to offshore. RCCA’s survey methods are based on visual census survey methods developed by the Partnership of Interdisciplinary Studies of Coastal Oceans (PISCO) and have been modified so that they can be taught in a reasonable amount of time to volunteer suba divers. Species are selected because of their ecological or economic importance or because they are of specific management interest.

Invertebrates are counted on 6 transects per site (3 transects in each zone). To be counted invertebrates have to be larger than 2.5 centimeters. Gorgonians and ‘large anemones‘ have to be larger than 10 centimeters to be counted. Each transect is a 2m wide x 30m long swath along the seafloor and flashlights are used to search in substrate crevices but no rocks are moved to find invertebrates. If more than 50 individuals of an invertebrate species are counted along the transect this species is sub-sampled. Sub-sampling is done by counting about 50 individuals and recording the distance along the transect at which this number of individuals is reached. Therefore, to generate densities for a 60 square meter area the count needs to be divided by the distance variable and then multiplied by 30. Abalone are not only counted but also measured and their size is recorded to the nearest centimeter.
For a complete description of the algae sampling methods see the RCCA monitoring protocol.

project.title: Reef Check kelp forest long-term MPA monitoing:invertebrate transects

funding.para: California Sea Grant, University of California, San Diego

otherEntity.entityDescription: The table that this metadata record refers to contains the monitoring site lookup information for Reef Check California's long-term MPA monitoring.

attribute.attributeDefinition: This code identifies the research group that collected the data. "RCCA" stands for Reef Check California.
The unique short code that identifies the long-term MPA monitoring project that the survey was a part of. 'NA' indicated that a site is not part of the long-term MPA monitoring program.
Unique codes for each location where sampling is conducted across all Reef Check monitoring sites.
The name of the California Marine Protected Area that the site is located in as defined in the CA_MPA_Boundary_Table. If the site is outside of an MPA (reference site) no MPA name is listed.
Describes if a site is inside (MPA) or outside of an MPA and used as reference site (REF). Some sites are inside MPAs but also used as references site for other MPAs they have the value MPA/REF.

codeDefinition.definition: Site is outside of MPA and used as MPA refernce site.
Site is not part of MPA monitoring
Site is in MPA and used as refercnes site for another MPA

attribute.attributeDefinition: Latitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Longitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2006.

codeDefinition.definition: Indicates that site was monitored in that year.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Indicates if a site was monitored in 2007.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2008.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2009.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2010.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2011.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2012.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2013.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2014.
Indicates if a site was monitored in 2015.

Indicates if a site was monitored in 2017.

Indicates if a site was monitored in 2019.

otherEntity.entityDescription: The table that this metadata record refers to contains the invertebrate species lookup data for Reef Check California's long-term MPA monitoring. It defines the species names used in the RCCA_invertebrate_data_table.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Taxonomic kingdom of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
Taxonomic phylum of the species or species group refereed to under Classcode.
Taxonomic class of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
Taxonomic order of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
Taxonomic family of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
Taxonomic genus of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
Taxonomic species name of the species or species group referred to under Classcode.
The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted, as defined in the classification in this lookup table.
WoRMS website from which the taxonomic information was obtained
AphiaID for taxon from WoRMS database.

otherEntity.entityDescription: This manual is a complete description of the Reef Check California survey methods.
This file contains the RCCA invertebrate swath data. These are species counts along 30m transects.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique site code that indicates where the survey was performed. This site code refers to a specific entry in the RCCA_site_table.
The Day of the month that the survey was done. This date is expressed in D or DD format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The month that the survey was done. This month is expressed in M or MM format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The year that the survey was done. This year is expressed in YYYY format.
Date that the survey was done.

A number representing one of the parallel transects through the study site. Core transects (i.e. transects at which fish, invertebrate, algae, and substrate data is collected) are numbered 1 to 6 with the transects in the offshore zone numbered as 1 to 3 and the inshore core transects numbered 4 to 6. Fish-only transects are numbered 7 to 18 with the offshore transects numbered 7 to 12 and the inshore transects numbered 13 to 18.
The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted. The taxonomy of the species is defined in the RCCA_invertebrate_lookup_table.
Total number of individuals of a given Classcode counted within the distance indicated in the Distance column along a transect.

Distance along transect over which individuals of a given Classcode were counted. When this distance is less than 30m, the species was sub-sampled. To generate densities for a 60 square meter area the Amount variable needs to be divided by the Distance variable and multiplied by 30.
Latitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Longitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Average depth of the transect in feet. Calculated from measurements taken at the beginning and the end of the transect measured by diver using dive computer.
Water temperature in Celsius at 10 meter depth as measured with dive computer in one location at the survey site.
Visibility in meters at the transect location as determined by divers by measuring the distance from which the fingers on a hand help up into the water column can be counted.

otherEntity.entityDescription: Sizes of abalone counted on RCCA invert transects.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique site code that indicates where the survey was performed. This site code refers to a specific entry in the site table.
The Day of the month that the survey was done. This date is expressed in D or DD format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The month that the survey was done. This month is expressed in M or MM format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The year that the survey was done. This year is expressed in YYYY format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
Date that the survey was done.

A number representing one of the parallel transects through the study site. Core transects (i.e. transects at which fish, invertebrate, algae, and substrate data is collected) are numbered 1 to 6 with the transects in the offshore zone numbered as 1 to 3 and the inshore core transects numbered 4 to 6. Fish-only transects are numbered 7 to 18 with the offshore transects numbered 7 to 12 and the inshore transects numbered 13 to 18.
The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted. The taxonomy of the species is defined in the species look up table.

Abalone size as measured across the longest dimension of the shell in cm. Prior to 2017 abalone sizes were estimated to the nearest cm. Starting in 2017 red abalone sizes north of the Golden Gate are measured with calipers to the nearest mm. In all other locations they continued to be estimated to nearest cm.
Latitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Longitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Average depth of the transect in feet. Calculated from measurements taken at the beginning and the end of the transect measured by diver using dive computer.
Water temperature in Celsius at 10 meter depth as measured with dive computer in one location at the survey site.
Visibility in meters at the transect location as determined by divers by measuring the distance from which the fingers on a hand help up into the water column can be counted.

otherEntity.entityDescription: Sizes of red and purple sea urchins.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The unique site code that indicates where the survey was performed. This site code refers to a specific entry in the site table.
The Day of the month that the survey was done. This date is expressed in D or DD format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The month that the survey was done. This month is expressed in M or MM format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
The year that the survey was done. This year is expressed in YYYY format. Dates reflect measurements taken in local time.
Date that the survey was done.
The unique taxonomic classification code that is being counted. The taxonomy of the species is defined in the species look up table.
Urchin test size is measured in 1 cm bins.
Number of urchins in a given size bin.
Latitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Longitude in decimal degrees calculated in the WGS84 geographic coordinate system. Transects are conducted within approximately 200 meters of this location.
Proximate depth in feet at which urchins were meassured.
Water temperature in Celsius at 10 meter depth as measured with dive computer in one location at the survey site.
